BhagavadGitaChapter.text: 2.1 Sanjaya said  Seeing Arjuna full of compassion and very sorrowful, his eyes brimming with tears, Madhusudana spoke these words.
BhagavadGitaChapter.meaning: Sanjaya said: "Seeing Arjuna overwhelmed with compassion, with eyes full of tears and greatly distressed, the Lord Madhusudana spoke these words to him."
BhagavadGitaChapter.explanation: On the battlefield of Kurukshetra, Arjuna is struck with deep sorrow at the thought of fighting his own relatives. His eyes fill with tears, and he is overcome with grief. Seeing this, Lord Krishna, referred to as Madhusudana, begins to counsel him on duty, righteousness, and the path to liberation.

BhagavadGitaChapter.text: 2.2 The Blessed Lord said  My dear Arjuna, how has this weakness come upon you at this critical moment? It is unworthy of a noble person, brings no honor, and will not lead to heaven.
BhagavadGitaChapter.meaning: The Blessed Lord said: "O Arjuna, how has this faint-heartedness appeared at such a time? This is not suitable for a noble person, does not lead to heaven, and brings only dishonor."
BhagavadGitaChapter.explanation: Krishna chastises Arjuna for his momentary weakness and attachment. He reminds him that this despair is unbecoming of a warrior and emphasizes that his duty as a Kshatriya is to fight righteously. This verse is meant to awaken Arjuna's courage and sense of duty.
